overview:
## Overview

HealthKit uses correlations to represent both blood pressure and food.

In general, a food correlation should include at least a [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKQuantityTypeIdentifier/dietaryEnergyConsumed] sample. You can also add nutritional quantity samples for any other items you want to track. Use the [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKMetadataKeyFoodType] key to indicate the food’s name.

The [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKCorrelation] class is a concrete subclass of the [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKSample] class. Correlations are immutable: You set the correlation’s properties when the object is first created, and they cannot change.

### Extend Correlation Samples

Like many HealthKit classes, the `HKCorrelation` class should not be subclassed. You can extend the correlation class by adding metadata with custom keys as appropriate for your app.

For more information, see the [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKCorrelation/init(type:start:end:objects:metadata:)] method.

# HKCorrelation

**Class**

A sample that groups multiple related samples into a single entry.

## Declaration

```swift
class HKCorrelation
```

## Overview

HealthKit uses correlations to represent both blood pressure and food.

- Blood pressure correlations always include two quantity samples, representing the systolic and diastolic values.
- Food correlations can contain a wide range of dietary information about the food, including information about the fat, protein, carbohydrates, energy, and vitamins consumed.

In general, a food correlation should include at least a [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKQuantityTypeIdentifier/dietaryEnergyConsumed] sample. You can also add nutritional quantity samples for any other items you want to track. Use the [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKMetadataKeyFoodType] key to indicate the food’s name.

The [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKCorrelation] class is a concrete subclass of the [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKSample] class. Correlations are immutable: You set the correlation’s properties when the object is first created, and they cannot change.

### Extend Correlation Samples

Like many HealthKit classes, the `HKCorrelation` class should not be subclassed. You can extend the correlation class by adding metadata with custom keys as appropriate for your app.

For more information, see the [doc://com.apple.healthkit/documentation/HealthKit/HKCorrelation/init(type:start:end:objects:metadata:)] method.

## Creating Correlations

- **init(type:start:end:objects:)**: Instantiates and returns a new correlation instance.
- **init(type:start:end:objects:metadata:)**: Instantiates and returns a new correlation instance with the provided metadata.
- **init(type:start:end:objects:device:metadata:)**: Instantiates and returns a new correlation instance with the provided device and metadata.

## Getting Correlation Data

- **correlationType**: The type for this correlation.
- **objects**: The set of sample objects that make up the correlation.
- **objects(for:)**: Returns a set containing all the objects of the specified type in the correlation.

## Specifying Predicate Key Paths

- **HKPredicateKeyPathCorrelation**: The key path for accessing the object’s correlation inside a predicate format string.

## Basic samples

- **HKCumulativeQuantitySample**: A sample that represents a cumulative quantity.
- **HKDiscreteQuantitySample**: A sample that represents a discrete quantity.
- **HKQuantitySample**: A sample that represents a quantity, including the value and the units.
- **HKCategorySample**: A sample with values from a short list of possible values.
- **Units and quantities**: Objects used to specify a quantity for a given unit, and to convert between units.
- **Metadata Keys**: Constants used to add metadata to objects stored in HealthKit.

## Inherits From

- HKSample

## Conforms To

- CVarArg
- CustomDebugStringConvertible
- CustomStringConvertible
- Equatable
- Hashable
- NSCoding
- NSObjectProtocol
- NSSecureCoding
- Sendable
- SendableMetatype
